title-group.article-title: In vitro cytotoxicity and cellular uptake of curcumin-loaded Pluronic/Polycaprolactone micelles in colorectal adenocarcinoma cells

article-meta.aff: Facility for nano/microparticles based biomaterials for advanced drug delivery systems (FADDS), Division of Biosurface Technology, Biomedical Technology Wing, Sree Chitra Tirunal Institute for Medical Sciences & Technology, Poojappura, Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala 695012, India

author-notes.corresp: Chandra P Sharma, FADDS, Division of Biosurface Technology, Biomedical Technology Wing, Sree Chitra Tirunal Institute for Medical Science and Technology, Poojappura, Thiruvananthapuram 695012, Kerala, India. Email: sharmacp@sctimst.ac.in

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Clinical application of curcumin has been limited due to poor aqueous solubility and consequently minimal systemic bioavailability. We investigated the preparation of curcumin-loaded micelles based on amphiphilic Pluronic/Polycaprolactone (Pluronic/PCL) block copolymer, which proved to be efficient in enhancing curcumin’s aqueous solubility. Curcumin-loaded micelles of size below 200 nm was characterized by dynamic light scattering and transmission electron microscopy. The critical micelle concentration (CMC) of the amphiphilic polymer was determined using pyrene as a fluorescent probe. Hemolysis and aggregation studies were investigated to evaluate the blood compatibility of the micelles. Sodium dodecyl sulphate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis was performed to study the stability of the micelles toward plasma proteins. In vitro cytotoxicity and cellular uptake of the curcumin-loaded micelles were demonstrated in colorectal adenocarcinoma (Caco2) cells. The results indicated that Pluronic/PCL micelles could be a promising candidate for curcumin delivery to cancer cells.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Bioavailability and efficacy of most of the drugs are affected by their hydrophobic nature. Nanoparticle-mediated drug delivery has reformed the administration of hydrophobic drugs, which have been facing a major setback due to their aqueous insolubility.1,2 In addition to sequestration and solubilization of hydrophobic drugs, the ability to ultimately release the drugs is also included in the profile of efficient drug delivery systems. During the last 20 years, polymeric drug carriers have immensely gained attention and have emerged as prospective drug delivery systems.3,4 Studies have been focused on polymeric micelles with self-assembly properties for drug delivery applications.5 Development of polymeric micelles as carriers for hydrophobic drugs provides a set of evident advantages which include efficient solubilization, increased bioavailability, and protection of the incorporated drug from inactivation in biological surroundings. Polymeric micelles have been considered as a versatile nanomedicinal platform due to their greatly improved drug pharmacokinetics and efficacious response in cancer treatment.6 Low water solubility, short blood half-lives, narrow therapeutic indices, and high systemic toxicity are the undesirable factors which have been associated with typical chemotherapeutic agents leading to patient morbidity and mortality. Polymeric micelles have been demonstrated as potent drug carriers by increasing the aqueous solubility of chemotherapeutic agents and prolonging their in vivo half-lives with lessened systemic toxicity.7–9 Micelles have also been reported to be suitable for enhanced tumor deposition due to the enhanced permeability and retention (EPR) effect stemming from the leakiness of tumor vasculature.10

Curcumin (1,7-bis (4-hydroxy-3-methoxyphenyl)-1,6-heptadiene-3,5 dione), a polyphenol, is a major constituent of turmeric, which is derived from the rhizomes of Curcuma longa. Traditional Indian medicine has unlocked various medicinal properties of turmeric. Later, through extensive research, it has been established that curcumin is the key compound in turmeric that imparts the therapeutic properties. Curcumin has been in the limelight ever since its potency for anticancer activity has been proved in various cancer cell lines.11,12 It has been shown to interact with many cellular targets such as nuclear factor-kappa B (NF-kB), transcription factor activator protein-1 (AP-1), and many other proteins,13,14 which explains curcumin’s potency for anticancer activity. Curcumin has also been reported to inhibit various interleukins, multiple protein kinases, and suppress the expression of human epidermal growth factor receptor (HER-2), epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), and estrogen receptor (ER).15,16 However, the clinical administration of this active molecule is hampered due to its low aqueous solubility, which further limits its bioavailability. One of the best methods to increase bioavailability is to encapsulate curcumin within the hydrophobic core of a micellar nanocarrier.17,18 However, despite successful encapsulation, the loading efficiency of curcumin is a factor which gets compromised.

In this study, we report the synthesis of Pluronic/Polycaprolactone (Pluronic/PCL) micelles and encapsulation of curcumin as a model drug into the amphiphilic core to improve its loading efficiency. Pluronic/PCL block copolymers have been previously reported to efficiently encapsulate hydrophobic indomethacin and paclitaxel.19,20 Curcumin encapsulation in this matrix has not yet been reported, which prompted us to incorporate the amphiphilic copolymer for our study. The PCL was selected as the core to load the hydrophobic curcumin based on its biocompatibility and biodegradability. Pluronic block copolymers are polyethylene oxide-polypropylene oxide-polyethylene oxide triblock (PEO-PPO-PEO) copolymers, which are approved by FDA for pharmaceutical and medical applications. The key attributes of Pluronic block copolymers apart from providing stability to nanoparticles are their ability to enhance drug transport by effective passive targeting toward cancerous tissues and sensitizing the multidrug resistance tumors to various anticancer agents. Due to their amphiphilic character, these copolymers display surfactant properties and further offers stability and biocompatibility to nanoparticles by minimizing the opsonization and prolonging the in vivo circulation of nanoparticles.21 Curcumin loading in Pluronic copolymers has been previously investigated and the matrix afforded a drug loading 5.7% weight by weight (w/w) with an encapsulation efficiency of 34%.22 In this work, we aimed at incorporating hydrophobic PCL with Pluronic as this was considered to increase the loading efficiency of curcumin. Release, cytotoxicity, and cellular uptake profile of the curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL matrix were also assessed.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: The ε-caprolactone, Pluronic F-127 (molecular weight 12,600 g/mol), stannous octoate, curcumin from Curcuma longa (Turmeric; Product no: C1386), pyrene, 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)−2,5-diphenyl tetrazolium bromide (MTT), and Dulbecco’s modified eagles medium (DMEM) were purchased from Sigma (Bangalore, India). Fetal bovine serum (FBS) was from GIBCO (United States). Colorectal adenocarcinoma (Caco2) cells were obtained from National Centre for Cell Science (Pune, India). All the solvents used in the study were of analytical grade and obtained from Merck (India). The blood experiment which involved collection of blood from healthy volunteers was approved by the Institute Ethics Committee.

sec.title: Synthesis of Pluronic/PCL
sec.p: Pluronic/PCL amphiphilic block copolymers were synthesized by the ring opening polymerization of ε-caprolactone in the presence of PEO-PPO-PEO triblock copolymer (Pluronic) using stannous octoate as the catalyst.23 Calculated amounts of PEO-PPO-PEO triblock copolymer and ε-caprolactone monomer (weight ratio = 1:2) were reacted under nitrogen atmosphere. Stannous octoate (0.5% w/w of total feed stock) was added to catalyze the polymerization reaction. The reaction was heated at 140°C for 12 h. The reaction product was then cooled to room temperature. The obtained viscous material was dissolved in dichloromethane and further precipitated in diethyl ether. The resulting product was filtered and vacuum dried.

sec.title: Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy
sec.p: The structure of the synthesized block polymer was characterized by Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra and was recorded using a Thermo Nicolet, 5700 (Germany) spectrometer. The FTIR spectra were obtained in the region 400–4000 cm−1.

sec.title: 1H nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy
sec.p: The1H nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) spectra of Pluronic/PCL was measured in deuterated chloroform (CDCl3) using a 500 MHz spectrometer (Bruker Avance DPX 300). Tetramethylsilane (TMS) was used as the internal standard. The analysis was performed at 22°C and the number of transients during the measurements was set as 16. The relaxation time of the instrument during measurements was 3.17 s. All other parameters were in the default settings of the instrument as per the specifications of Bruker Avance DPX 300.

sec.title: Gel permeation chromatography
sec.p: The molecular weight distribution of the block polymer and weight average molecular weight (Mw) was determined by gel permeation chromatography (GPC, Waters HPLC system 600 Series Pump, Milford, United States). Styragel columns-HR-5 E/4E/2/0.5 were used in series. The 2414 refractive index detector and Waters 717 plus autosampler were used. Polystyrene standards used for relative calibration was of peak average molar mass (Mp) 100,000, 34,300, and 1470. The mobile phase was tetrahydrofuran (THF) with a flow-rate of 1 mL/min. The injection volume was usually 100 mL of stock solutions (0.1–0.5 w/v%).

sec.title: Particle size and zeta potential
sec.p: The size of the curcumin-loaded micelles was assessed by dynamic light scattering (Nano-ZS 90, Malvern Instrument, United Kingdom). The temperature was kept at 25°C during the measuring process and measurements were recorded as the average of three test runs. The zeta potential of the micellar solutions were measured in folded capillary cells using Nanosizer (Malvern Instrument, United Kingdom). Transmission electron microscope (TEM) experiments were performed on a Hitachi H-7650 (Tokyo, Japan) at an acceleration voltage of 80 kV. Curcumin-loaded micellar suspensions were administered onto a 200 mesh Formvar-coated copper grids and air-dried prior to imaging.

sec.title: Differential scanning calorimetry
sec.p: Differential scanning calorimetric (DSC) studies were carried out to define the physical state of curcumin in the carrier and the possibility of any interaction between curcumin and the loaded polymeric matrix. The DSC curves were recorded on a scanning calorimeter equipped with a thermal analysis data system (DSC Q20). Small amounts of the samples were placed in hermetically sealed aluminum pans and heated from 25 to 300°C at a heat flow-rate of 10°C/min under nitrogen spurge.

sec.title: UV-visible and fluorescence spectroscopy
sec.p: The photophysical properties of the curcumin-loaded polymeric micelles were analyzed by ultraviolet (UV) spectrometer (Cary model 100 BioUV-Vis spectrophotometer, Varian Australia Pty Ltd, Victoria, Australia). The fluorescence emission spectra of free curcumin and curcumin-loaded polymeric micelles were recorded from 450 to 700 nm with an excitation wavelength of 420 nm on a fluorescence spectrophotometer (Infinite M200, TECAN). The slit widths were set at 5 and 3.5 nm for excitation and emission wavelength, respectively.

sec.title: Determination of block length of Pluronic/PCL
sec.p: The block length of the PCL (LPCL) was determined from the NMR spectral analysis according to a previously reported calculation.24 The following equation was used for the calculation: LPCL=LPluronic ×3(peak intensity of CH2 group of PCL)2(peak intensity of CH3 group in PPO of pluronic)/2 where, LPluronic is the block length of PPO in Pluronic.

A triblock structure was assumed for the PCL-Pluronic-PCL copolymer and the number-average molecular weight (Mn) was computed using the equation below: (2)Mn of copolymer=Mn of pluronic+2LPCL×114 where 114 is the molecular weight of caprolactone (CL) monomer.

sec.title: Critical micelle concentration
sec.p: The CMC of the synthesized block polymer was determined by fluorescence spectroscopy using pyrene as fluorescence probe. The fluorescence spectrum was recorded on a fluorescence spectrophotometer (Infinite M200, TECAN). The pyrene solution prepared at a concentration of 6.0 × 10−7 M in acetone were added to the test tubes and evaporated to remove the solvent. The micellar solutions in deionized water were added to the test tubes in concentrations ranging from 3.9 to 500 µg/mL bringing the final concentration of pyrene to 1.0 × 10−7 M. The solutions were vortexed and kept overnight at 37°C to equilibrate pyrene with the micelles. At an excitation wavelength of 360 nm, emission spectra of the micelles in pyrene solution were monitored by the spectrofluorometer.

sec.title: Preparation of curcumin-loaded polymeric micelle by solvent dialysis method
sec.p: A total of 30 mg Pluronic/PCL was dissolved in 10 mL of dimethylformamide (DMF) solution. To this solution, varying amounts of 3 mg (9.09% w/w), 4 mg (11.76% w/w), 5 mg (14.28% w/w), and 6 mg (16.66% w/w) of curcumin were added and stirred at room temperature. This DMF solution was directly dialyzed for 24 h against 3 L of ultrapure water (resistivity 18.2 Ωm) using cellulose dialysis membranes (molecular weight cutoff: 12 kDa, manufacturer, Sigma). The water was changed three times during the dialysis process. The micellar solution from dialysis bag was collected and centrifuged at 5000 rpm for 15 min to settle the unloaded curcumin. The micellar solution obtained, free from the pelleted curcumin, was frozen at −80°C and then lyophilized using a lyophilizer (Labconco, United States) to obtain a dry powder of curcumin-loaded micellar products for further use.

sec.title: Curcumin encapsulation
sec.p: The percentage of encapsulated curcumin was determined by centrifuging the micellar solution, obtained after dialysis, at 5000 rpm for 15 min. The pelleted (unencapsulated) curcumin was dissolved in methanol and was spectrophotometrically quantified using UV spectrometer (Cary model 100 BioUV-Vis spectrophotometer, Varian, Australia) at a wavelength of 430 nm. The encapsulation efficiency was calculated using the following equation: Encapsulation efficiency (%) =Total amount of curcumin-Free curcuminTotal amount of curcumin×1 00.

sec.title: In vitro release
sec.p: Lyophilized curcumin-loaded polymer-conjugated fatty esters were redispersed in 33 mL of 0.01 M PBS solution (pH 7.4) at a formulation concentration of 300 µg/mL. Total volume was divided into 33 eppendorff tubes giving 11 different sets (each set with 3 Eppendorff tubes for the triplicates) for time-dependent release study at time intervals of 2, 4, 6, 12, 24, 36, 48, 60, 72, 96, and 108 h. Free curcumin is completely insoluble in PBS; therefore, at predetermined intervals of time, the solution was centrifuged at 1000 rpm for 5 min to separate the released (pelleted) curcumin from the micelles. At definite time intervals, released amounts of curcumin in loaded micelles were extracted in methanol and quantified at 430 nm using UV-visible spectrophotometer.25 The release was quantified as follows: Release (%)=Released curcuminTotal curcumin×1 00.

sec.title: Solubility and stability study of curcumin-loaded micelles
sec.p: Free curcumin and curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL particles were dissolved in PBS to observe the aqueous solubility. To study the stability of curcumin in the micelles, free curcumin (dissolved with addition of methanol; final methanol concentration less than 5% volume by volume [v/v]) and the loaded micelles in PBS (0.01 M, pH 7.4) at a concentration of 40 µg/mL (total of 10 mL solution) were incubated in a shaker for 8 h at 37°C with a rotation speed of 150 rpm. A total of 100 µL of sample solutions were taken and added to 900 µL of methanol and quantified spectrophotometrically at 430 nm.

sec.title: Electrophoresis analysis of polymer–plasma protein interactions
sec.p: Sodium dodecyl sulphate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS PAGE) analysis was performed to detect the interaction of Pluronic/PCL copolymers with plasma proteins. Pluronic/PCL copolymers were incubated with human plasma (diluted with saline) for 1 h at 37°C. The samples were then centrifuged at 10,000 rpm for 10 min and 20 µL of the supernatant was loaded on 7% resolving and 4% stacking gel at 100 V for 90 min using Mini-PROTEAN II electrophoresis system (Bio-Rad, CA, United States). The gel was stained with coomassie blue and documented using an image analyzer (LAS 4000, Fuji). Plasma incubated with normal saline (0.09% sodium chloride [NaCl]) was considered as the control.

sec.title: Hemolysis
sec.p: For performing the hemolysis and aggregation studies, the human blood sample was collected in a tube containing 3.8% sodium citrate at ratio 9:1 (blood:anticoagulant). A total of 200 µL of blood was mixed with 800 µL of saline and was centrifuged at 750 rpm for 10 min. The erythrocytes obtained after repeated washings (plasma-free) were resuspended in fresh saline and vortexed. A total of 100 µL of the pellet was added to the empty and curcumin-loaded micellar solutions, which were kept for incubation at 37°C for 2 h. The absorbances were measured at 541 nm. Normal saline was used as negative control and distilled water as positive control.26 Percentage of hemolysis was calculated using the following equation: Percentage of hemolysis =OD of test solution-OD of negative controlOD of positive control-OD of negative control where OD refers to optical density.

sec.title: Red blood cell aggregation
sec.p: Human erythrocytes were collected by centrifugation of whole blood at 700 rpm for 10 min and then diluted with saline at 1:10 ratio. To 100 µL of erythrocytes, 100 µL curcumin-loaded and unloaded micelles were added and incubated for 1 h at 37°C. Normal saline (0.09% NaCl) and polyethylenimine (PEI) were used as the negative and positive controls, respectively.27 After incubation, the cells were isolated by centrifugation and the aggregation images were captured on a phase contrast microscope (Leica DM IRB, Germany).

sec.title: White blood cell aggregation
sec.p: The white blood cell (WBC) compatibility study was done with anticoagulated blood (1 mL) overlaid with histopaque (1 mL) in order to make three separate layers and was centrifuged for 15 min at 800 rpm at room temperature. The collected WBC was incubated with the micelles for 1 h at 37 °C. Aggregation was detected through phase contrast microscope (Leica DM IRB, Germany).

sec.title: Platelet aggregation
sec.p: The platelet layer was isolated from the anticoagulated blood overlaid with histopaque and the platelets were incubated with micelles at 37°C for 1 h. Detection of aggregation was done through phase contrast microscope (Leica DM IRB, Germany).

sec.title: Cytotoxicity studies – MTT assay
sec.p: In order to check the cytotoxicities of various concentrations of curcumin-loaded polymeric micelles, MTT assay was done on Caco2 cell lines. These cells were seeded in culture flasks with DMEM medium along with 10% FBS and incubated for 24 h at 37°C in 5% CO2 and 95% humidity to attain a cell growth of 80% confluency. Prior to the experiment, the cells were trypsinized and transferred to a 24-well cell culture plate at a density of 1 × 105cells/well. Dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) was added to aid the solubility of curcumin in aqueous media. The final concentration of DMSO in the culture medium was ensured to be less than 0.1%. The cells were exposed to a series of different concentrations of free and encapsulated curcumin (2.5–20 µM) for 48 h followed by addition of 100 µL MTT (0.5 mg/mL) and incubated for 3 h at 37°C. Formazan crystals formed were dissolved with the addition 300 µL of DMSO per well. An incubation period of 15 min at 37°C was provided. The absorbance was measured at 570 nm using a plate reader (Finstruments Micro plate Reader, United States). The cells treated with medium were used as negative control. Cytotoxicity of the unloaded micelles were also assessed in the similar manner. The percentage viability was calculated as: Cell viability (%)=Nt/Nc×1 00 where Nt was the absorbance of the cells treated with free curcumin or curcumin-loaded micelles and Nc was the absorbance of the untreated cells.

sec.title: Cellular uptake studies – fluorescence microscopy
sec.p: The Caco2 cells were grown in 35 mm culture plate up to 80% confluency to visualize the cellular uptake of curcumin-loaded micelles. The molar concentration of curcumin used for the uptake study was 10 µM. All the samples were dissolved in PBS (0.01 M, pH 7.4) and as free curcumin was insoluble in aqueous solution, it was dissolved with the aid of DMSO and then diluted with PBS. Cells were treated with free curcumin and curcumin-loaded micelles. They were incubated for 4 h prior to viewing under a fluorescence microscope (Leica DMI3000) for intracellular curcumin fluorescence.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Data are represented as mean ± standard deviation (SD) of three independent experiments. Statistical analysis of the data was performed via one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) using SPSS software (SPSS-16, IBM, USA); a value of p < 0.05 was considered significant (n = 3).

sec.title: Synthesis and characterization of curcumin-loaded polymeric micelles
sec.p:
Stannous octoate due to its low cost and high efficiency was the catalyst of choice for lactone polymerization. Stannous octoate-mediated ring-opening polymerization of ε-caprolactone and Pluronic afforded the formation of Pluronic/PCL block copolymer. Figure 1 represents the reaction scheme for the synthesis. The mechanism involved the metal species functioning as a catalyst and the end hydroxyl group of the Pluronic serving as an initiator. The active hydrogen atom at one end of the Pluronic chain acted as an initiator and induced a selective acyl-oxygen cleavage of ε-caprolactone. A strong carbonyl band at 1736 cm−1 indicated the formation of Pluronic/PCL block copolymer (Figure 2(a)). No significant difference was observed in the spectral pattern for the different sets of Pluronics. Bands at 2943 and 2865 cm−1 were also observed and was believed to occur due to the overlapping of the aliphatic CH stretching band of PCL and Pluronic, respectively.24 Absence of the OH stretching peak of curcumin at 3505 cm−1 (IR spectrum of curcumin not shown) and a shift in the C = O absorption of the loaded Pluronic/PCL to a lower wave number (1723 cm−1), which was attributed to the formation of intermolecular hydrogen bonds between the hydroxyl group of curcumin and the carbonyl group of the copolymer, suggested the encapsulation of curcumin(Figure 2(b)).28 The1H NMR spectra showed a sharp singlet at ∼3.63 ppm due to the protons of CH2CH2 units of PEO. The doublet at 1.129 ppm corresponded to CH3 protons in PPO. The CH and CH2 units of PPO were depicted by the peaks at ∼3.39 and 3.5 ppm. Two intense triplets at 4.05 and 2.30 ppm were observed in addition to the multiplets at ∼1.4 and 1.6 ppm, which were attributed to the PCL block (Figure 3). Our spectral analysis was in accordance with the1H NMR characterization of Pluronic/PCL in a previously reported work.24 The average molecular weight (Mw) of the copolymer using the1H NMR data and applying the Equations (1) and (2) was 28,201. The LPCL in Pluronic/PCL was calculated as 68.34. The molecular weight obtained from GPC was 26,663 with a polydispersity index of 1.66. Formation of a tri-block structure was confirmed from the similar values in the molecular weights obtained from NMR and GPC analysis. Figure 1.
Reaction scheme for the ring opening polymerization of ε-caprolactone and Pluronic using stannous octoate as catalyst.
Figure 2.
Infra red (IR) spectrum. (a) Pluronic/PCL and (b) curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL.
Figure 3.
The1H nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) spectrum of Pluronic/PCL.

sec.title: CMC of Pluronic/PCL copolymers
sec.p: Application of pyrene as a fluorescence probe, based on changes in the intensity of the vibrational bands of pyrene, is a widely used methodology for determining the CMC. The relative peak intensity of pyrene undergoes significant perturbation upon transition from polar to nonpolar solvents. The ratio of the fluorescence intensity of the first vibrational band (370 nm), the highest energy vibrational band, to that of the third vibrational band (402 nm) has been shown to correlate with solvent polarity.29 In polar environment, pyrene behaves as a self-quenching agent but exhibits fluorescence when located in the proximity of hydrophopic domain of a micelle.

The Pluronic/PCL block copolymer arranged into its micellar form in aqueous medium forcing pyrene molecules to move into the micelles from the aqueous phase. This transition altered the intensity ratio of (I370/I402) of pyrene fluorescence bands. It was also observed that with increased polymer concentrations, the intensity also increased as pyrene was shifted to the hydrophobic interior. The CMC value was measured from the point of inflection of the sigmoid curve (Figure 4). The CMC value calculated for Pluronic/PCL was 4.2 × 10−7 M. A high CMC value of Pluronic block copolymers limits their applications in drug delivery.30 Incorporation of PCL afforded a lower CMC value, which signified enhanced hydrophobicity that enabled the easy micelle formation of Pluronic/PCL. This indicated that the micelles may be useful as drug carriers as they could maintain a micelle structure even upon dilution with a large volume of blood. Figure 4.
Critical micelle concentration (CMC) measurement by using pyrene as a fluorescence probe.

sec.title: Curcumin loading and encapsulation efficiency
sec.p: Curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL micelles were prepared by dialysis method. The dialysis method consists in bringing the drug and copolymer from organic solvent in which they are both soluble to a solvent that is selective only for the hydrophilic part of the polymer (e.g., water). As the organic solvent is replaced by the selective one, the hydrophobic portion of the polymer associates to form the micellar core incorporating the insoluble drug during the process. Curcumin was loaded into the inner hydrophobic core of the Pluronic/PCL micelles by adopting similar strategy.

The loading efficiency of curcumin is a factor which gets compromised despite high encapsulation efficiency. Curcumin delivery in self-assembling methoxy poly (ethylene glycol)–palmitate nanocarrier of Sahu et al. exhibited loading efficiency of 1% despite an encapsulation close to 100%.17 We carried out curcumin loading in Pluronic/PCL micelles at 9.09, 11.76, and 14.28% w/w, which afforded an encapsulation efficiency of 96.59 ± 1.01, 87.03 ± 2.21, and 72.08 ± 4.29%, respectively. This corresponded to an actual loading of 8.781 ± 0.09, 10.224 ± 0.26, and 10.29 ± 0.61% w/w. Precipitation of curcumin was observed when 16.66% w/w loading was performed, and hence, theoretical loading of 14.28% w/w was chosen as the optimized loading efficiency for further in vitro studies. Mohanty et al. performed a 9% w/w theoretical curcumin loading with 57% encapsulation efficiency with methoxy polyethylene glycol (mPEG)/PCL di-block copolymeric micelles.31 Incorporation of Pluronic in our study showed an improvement in the loading efficiency of curcumin compared to the mPEG/PCL micelles. We could attain an encapsulation efficiency of 72% with 14% w/w theoretical curcumin loading. This could be attributed to the presence of propylene oxide moieties in the Pluronic, which were capable of enhancing the hydrophobicity of the micellar core thereby increasing the curcumin encapsulation.

sec.title: Particle size and zeta potential measurement
sec.p:
Particle size is an important parameter as it can directly affect the physical stability, cellular uptake, biodistribution, and drug release from the nanoparticles.32 The particle sizes of the unloaded Pluronic/PCL micelles determined by dynamic light scattering (DLS) are shown in Table 1. Encapsulation of curcumin was evident from the gradual increase in the size of micelles with the increased curcumin loading. Figure 5 depicts the TEM image of curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL (14% w/w). The size of the micelles observed in the TEM image were smaller than that obtained in DLS and the reason could be attributed to the shrinkage of the hydrophilic backbone during the sample preparation for TEM. Figure 5.
Transmission electron microscope (TEM) image of curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL micelles.
Table 1.
Effect of curcumin-loading on Pluronic/PCL micelles.
Theoretical loading efficiency (%) Particle size (nm) Zeta potential (mV)
0 59.20 ± 0.6 −14.6 ± 1.2
9.09 88.4 ± 0.9 −16.5 ± 0.2
11.75 159.9 ± 3.3 −15.4 ± 0.5
14.28 195.7 ± 7.3 −17.6 ± 0.4

Information regarding a charged active material being encapsulated within the centre of the nanocapsule or adsorbed onto the surface can be gathered by zeta potential determination.33 The micelles had a zeta potential in the range of −14 to −17 mV (Table 1). Negligible change in the zeta potential indicated that curcumin was encapsulated inside the Pluronic/PCL micelles. Nanoparticles with a zeta potential above ±30 mV have been shown to be stable in suspension, as the surface charge prevents aggregation of the particles. The optimum zeta potential value of the curcumin-loaded micelles explained its stability in aqueous medium.

sec.title: Curcumin–copolymer interactions
sec.p:
The DSC is an accurate and rapid thermoanalytical technique, widely used by the pharmaceutical industry and in drug research, to investigate several physicochemical phenomena, such as polymorphism, melting and crystallization, purity, drug–excipient interaction, polymer properties, and so on.34 The physical status of curcumin encapsulated in the polymeric micelles was investigated by DSC. Free curcumin has an endothermic melting peak at 177.18°C implying its crystalline state.35 This peak was absent in the thermogram of curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL copolymers, which only exhibited the characteristic melting peaks of Pluronic/PCLs around 57°C (Figure 6 (a) and (b)). The absence of detectable crystalline domains of curcumin in the loaded micelles indicated that encapsulated curcumin was in the amorphous form in the polymeric matrix.36 The presence of drug in crystalline form inside nanoparticles can pose as an obstacle due to the difficulty in the diffusion of the large-sized molecules from the small pores of the nanoparticles. However, a sustained release of the encapsulated drug is possible if the drug is in amorphous phase, as it facilitates easy diffusion of drug molecules through the polymeric matrix. Figure 6.
Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) thermogram of (a) curcumin and (b) curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL.

sec.title: Photophysical characterization
sec.p:
Encapsulation of curcumin in the micelles was further confirmed by photophysical characterization studies. Distinct photophysical properties were exhibited by the curcumin-loaded micelles. Curcumin, solubilized in 10% methanolic solution, showed an absorption peak at 425 nm. Similar peak with a decrease in absorption intensity was exhibited by curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL micelles (Figure 7). In the fluorescence spectra, curcumin showed a weak broad peak at 550 nm and the curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL micelles showed a well-defined high-intensity blue-shifted fluorescent peak at 495 nm (Figure 8). This suggested the binding of curcumin to the hydrophobic core of the micelles.37 Recent report by Sahu et al. explained the shift in fluorescence spectra of curcumin-encapsulated bovine casein micelle, from 540 to 500 nm, due to the binding of curcumin in the hydrophobic domain of the protein molecule in micelle.16 Figure 7.
Ultra violet (UV)-visible absorption spectrum. (a) Curcumin in 10% methanolic solution and (b) curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL micelles.
Figure 8.
Fluorescence emission spectrum. (a) Curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL micelles and (b) curcumin in 10% methanolic solution.

sec.title: Interaction with plasma proteins
sec.p:
Understanding nanoparticle–protein interaction is a prominent factor, which helps in promoting applications of nanoparticles in the biomedical fields and reducing/preventing possible adverse effects to the biological systems caused by nanoparticles. The binding extent of plasma proteins with Pluronic/PCL micelles was examined by performing SDS PAGE (Figure 9). Lanes 2 and 3 corresponded to Pluronic/PCL and curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL, respectively. It was observed that the protein bands corresponding to most of the low molecular weight globular proteins were present in all the polymer–plasma samples. The protein bands were similar to the band obtained in Lane 1, which corresponded to normal saline indicating that the micelles did not bind with the plasma proteins. Surface induced thrombosis, which is one of the major problems in the clinical application of blood-contacting materials, begins with adsorption of plasma proteins to the surface.38,39 The lack of adherence of plasma proteins on the Pluronic/PCL micelles could be attributed to the PEO units in Pluronic, which are capable of prohibiting adsorption of proteins and cells depending on the surface density of PEO chains, their length, and dynamics.40 The biodistribution of the carrier is mainly dictated by the nature of the hydrophilic shell, which is responsible for micelle stabilization and interactions with plasma proteins and cell membranes.41 Figure 9.
Sodium dodecyl sulphate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS PAGE) showing the interactions of micelles with the plasma proteins. Lanes 2 and 3 corresponds to empty and curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL micelles, respectively. Lane 1 is the control performed with saline.

sec.title: Hemolysis study
sec.p: Hemocompatibility is a significant parameter to evaluate the responses that arises between drug carrier and blood, and it determines the safety parameter of the material in the human body. Plasma hemoglobin assay can be classified as direct optical technique, that is, quantification based on oxyhemoglobin’s absorbance peak.42 Oxyhemoglobin has strong absorption peak at 541 nm. Oxyhemoglobin will leak out from the lysed red blood cells (RBCs) and correspondingly high-intensity absorption peak would be obtained at 541 nm. For materials that do not induce hemolysis, this peak would be negligible.43

Negligible percentage (less than 1%) of hemolysis was observed in the case of empty and curcumin-loaded micelles, which indicated that the synthesized nanoparticles were compatible with the erythrocytes (Table 2). This was an expected observation as both the components of the micelles, Pluronic, and PCL are widely used matrices for biological applications. Curcumin’s ability to induce apoptosis in cancer cells without cytotoxic effects on healthy cells is well documented in the literature.44 The blood compatibility of the micelles was further visually revealed through aggregation studies. Table 2.
Hemolysis results.
Sample Hemolysis (%)
Pluronic127/PCL 0.0722 ± 0.003
Curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL 0.0765 ± 0.023
Saline (negative control) 0
Distilled water (positive control) 100

sec.title: RBC, WBC, and platelet aggregation
sec.p:
Blood cell aggregation is a highly undesirable phenomenon that can induce serious circulatory disorders, even lethal toxicity. Evaluation of blood compatibility is essential for materials developed for biological applications. Negligible aggregation was detected in RBC, WBC, and platelets incubated with the micelles indicating the nontoxic effect of the micelles on normal cells. The micrographs of human blood cells (RBC, WBC, and platelets) upon interaction with the loaded and unloaded micelles along with normal saline and PEI as controls are shown in Figures 10–12. It was observed that the micelles did not promote aggregation like the positive control, PEI. Positive controls in blood studies are materials that induce aggregation of the blood cells. The PEI is a cationic polymer and is reported to have strong toxicity and is often used as a positive control in blood aggregation studies.45 The nonaggregation of the micelles could be attributed to the Pluronic moiety. The use of Pluronic for modifying blood compatibility of materials is well documented in the literature and the improved antithrombogenicity of Pluronic can be attributed to the long polyethylene oxide chains, which are capable of suppressing blood cell adhesion.46 Figure 10.
Red blood cell (RBC) aggregation in (A) saline, (B) PEI, (C) Pluronic/PCL micelles, and (D) curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL micelles.
Figure 11.
White blood cell (WBC) aggregation in (A) saline, (B) PEI, (C) Pluronic/PCL micelles, and (D) curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL micelles. Figure 12.
Platelet aggregation in (A) saline, (B) PEI, (C) Pluronic/PCL micelles, and (D) curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL micelles.

sec.title: Solubility and stability of curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL micelles
sec.p:
Free curcumin was found to be sparingly soluble in aqueous solution with formation of visible undissolved microscopic flakes compared to the curcumin-loaded micellar solution (Figure 13). Instability and biodegradation in physiological pH are the major challenges faced by curcumin. Degradation of curcumin in aqueous solution has been attributed to hydrolysis and Wang et al. have reported the rapid hydrolytic degradation to occur above neutral pH.47 Partially deprotonated curcumin is transformed into trans-6 -(4′-hydroxy-3′-methoxyphenyl)−2,4-dioxo-5-hexenal upon fragmentation, which is further degraded to vanillin, feruloyl methane, and ferulic acid. The contribution of these molecules toward light absorption is negligible.48 This implied that a decrease in absorbance, while monitoring the degradation of curcumin, is due to the proportional decrease in the curcumin concentration. We attempted to study the biodegradation and stability of curcumin by incubating both free and encapsulated curcumin in PBS and estimated its concentration with time, spectrophotometrically. It was observed that only 5% of free curcumin remained intact after an incubation of 8 h, whereas 94% of curcumin encapsulated in the Pluronic/PCL micelles remained intact (Figure 14). Curcumin, due to its hydrophibicity, was presumed to be inside the core of the micelles and the copolymeric micelles were capable of protecting the encapsulated curcumin against biotransformation and hydrolysis. Figure 13.
Solubility study. (A) Free curcumin was insoluble in aqueous medium and (B) curcumin encapsulated in Pluronic/PCL micelles exhibited enhanced solubility.
Figure 14.
Stability of curcumin in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS; 0.01 M, pH 7.4) at 37°C. Values reported are mean ± standard deviation (SD), n = 3.

sec.title: In vitro release
sec.p:
A sustained release of curcumin was expected from DSC results based on the amorphous nature of curcumin in the Pluronic/PCL matrix and this was further confirmed by the in vitro release study. The curcumin release profile from the Pluronic/PCL micelles is pictured in Figure 15. After 108 h, 60.11 ± 2.6% of curcumin were released from Pluronic/PCL, respectively. The expected sustained release was observed after 20 h from the matrix. As evident from the in vitro release profile, curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL micelles may have the potential to serve as a sustained release matrix, since such drug delivery systems are much sought after for its less frequent administration leading to patient compliance. Figure 15.
In vitro release from curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL micelles at pH 7.4. Error bars represent means ± standard deviation (SD) for n = 3.

sec.title: Cytotoxicity studies – MTT assay
sec.p:
The MTT assay was performed on the empty and curcumin-loaded micelles. It was observed that Pluronic/PCL micelles did not exhibit any toxicity, which was in accordance with the hemolytic study. In all 100% cell viability was encountered at 3 mg/mL copolymer concentration (Figure 16(a)). The potential of curcumin to elicit apoptosis signals in a variety of tumor tissues, including colorectal, lung breast, pancreatic, and prostate carcinoma, is well documented in the literature.49,50 Levi-Ari et al. have suggested that curcumin’s apoptotic ability is related to the inhibition of the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase, which subsequently downregulates the expression of cyclooxygenase (COX-2).51,52 Inadequate water solubility and subsequent precipitation decreased the effective exposure time of the cells with free curcumin leading to relatively less cytotoxicity compared to the curcumin-loaded micelles (Figure 16(b)). Less than 60% cells were viable at a curcumin concentration of 10 μM in the curcumin-loaded micelles. Low cell viability of Caco2 cells was attributed to the enhanced aqueous solubility and effective cell internalization of the curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL micelles. Enhanced cytotoxicity could also be attributed to the presence of Pluronic. Yan et al. recently observed that the docetaxel-loaded Poly[lactic-co-glycolic acid] (PLGA)/poloxamer 188 nanoparticles achieved a significantly higher level of cytotoxicity than that of docetaxel-loaded PLGA nanoparticles and Taxotere.53 Similar observation had been reported by Mei et al. with docetaxel-loaded PCL/Pluronic F68 nanoparticles in docetaxel-resistant human breast cancer cell line, MCF-7 TAX30.54 Our cytotoxicity study affirmed that the transition of crystalline phase of curcumin to the amorphous state upon encapsulation did not hinder its anticancer potential and that the micellar encapsulation did not compromise curcumin’s therapeutic activity. Figure 16.
(a) Cytotoxicity study of empty Pluronic/PCL micelles on colorectal adenocarcinoma (Caco2) cells. Values reported are mean ± standard deviation (SD), n = 3. (b) Cytotoxicity study of curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL micelles in Caco2 cells compared to the native form. Significant difference was observed between control vs all concentrations of curcumin and curcumin-loaded micelles. There was significant difference between curcumin and curcumin-loaded micelles from concentration of 10 µM and above. Statistically significant difference (p < 0.05) is denoted by *. Values exhibited are mean ± SD, n = 3.

sec.title: Cellular uptake study
sec.p:
Green intrinsic fluorescence of curcumin is a widely exploited factor in the cellular uptake studies of curcumin. Curcumin has the advantage to be traced inside cells without being tagged by other fluorescent dyes. We confirmed the cellular internalization of curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL micelles by fluorescence microscopy in Caco2 cells. The empty copolymeric micelles did not exhibit any fluorescence (Figure 17(a)). Curcumin-loaded micelles showed intracellular green fluorescence proving that the Caco2 cells efficiently took up the micelles compared to the free curcumin. However, entry of free curcumin was not prominent in the cells owing to its low aqueous solubility (Figure 17(b) and (c)). Similar observations on the effect of curcumin-encapsulated Pluronic micelles in HeLa cells have been reported by Sahu et al.22 Micelles with Pluronic moiety have been known to undergo internalization in cells.55 Sahay et al. studied the endocytosis mechanism of Pluronic block copolymers, where they interfere with selected membrane trafficking processes by inserting their hydrophobic PPO chains into lipid bilayers and decreasing membrane microviscosity.56 The uptake of curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL micelles in the Caco2 cells could be attributed to these mechanisms induced by the Pluronic moiety. Figure 17.
Cellular internalization of (a) empty Pluronic/PCL micelles in colorectal adenocarcinoma (Caco2) cells, (b) free curcumin, and (c) curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL micelles in Caco2 cells under fluorescence microscopic view.

Poor absorption and bioavailability are serious problems concerning therapeutic application of hydrophobic, poorly water-soluble molecules, which compel many poorly soluble compounds to be excluded very early in their screening process, regardless of how active these compounds are toward their molecular targets.57,58 Curcumin, which suffers from low bioavailability problems, requires a suitable carrier/delivery system to overcome these obstacles without compromising its activity. Our study suggests that Pluronic/PCL delivery system could be a promising choice for administering curcumin without the loss of its therapeutic activity. The pronounced cellular uptake of the micelles in Caco2 cells and in vitro cytotoxicity profile of curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL micelles can be extrapolated to make it a promising cancer therapeutic.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: We attempted to synthesize Pluronic/PCL micelles for encapsulating the therapeutic agent, curcumin. The self-assembling tendency of the block copolymer in aqueous phase, indicated by their low CMC value, suggested the possibility of developing the micelles as a stable delivery vehicle for curcumin. Curcumin-loaded Pluronic/PCL micelles exhibited favorable loading, sustained release, and put forth better performance of in vitro cytotoxicity and cellular uptake in Caco2 cells compared to the native form. Our investigation highlighted the potential of Pluronic/PCL micelles to be considered as a suitable nanocarrier for curcumin for anticancer applications.
